title: Is it 'prescribed for' or 'prescribed to'? What is the correct usage? - Quora

response.answer_text: Actually it's about Grammer The matter of your question is about Grammer functions nor different meaning. Yeah maybe there is a different between using “to” or “for” for word “prescription” in vocabulary. But first, let me give you the rules of those two prepositions in Grammer “to” and “for”. To Used to indicate the place, person, or thing that someone or something moves toward, or the direction of something: I am heading to the entrance of the building.The package was mailed to Mr. Kim yesterday.All of us went to the movie theater.Please send it back to me.Used to indicate a limit or an ending point: The snow was piled up to the roof.The stock prices rose up to 100 dollars.Used to indicate relationship: This letter is very important to your admission.My answer to your question is in this envelop.Do not respond to every little thing in your life.Used to indicate a time or a period: I work nine to six, Monday to Friday.It is now 10 to five. (In other words, it is 4:50.)For Used to indicate the use of something: This place is for exhibitions and shows.I baked a cake for your birthday.I put a note on the door for privacy.She has been studying hard for the final exam.Used to mean because of: I am so happy for you.We feel deeply sorry for your loss.For this reason, I’ve decided to quit this job.Used to indicate time or duration: He’s been famous for many decades.I attended the university for one year only.This is all I have for today.Look focus on this point Used to indicate the use of something: So, it's better to say “the doctor prescribed a tablet for the child” (not to the child) It means he said “hey child, use those tablet after every snack” Hope you get the answer!

There is no real difference in casual conversation. Technically, however, "prescribed to" does not really exist. The "to" is not attached to "prescription."Example 1: The medicine is prescribed to children.Example 2: The medicine is prescribed to treat diabetes. However, the "for" is, in fact, attached to "prescription". Example 3: The doctor prescribed this medicine for my husband.Example 4: There are medicines prescribed for diabetes. Let me put it this way. Technically, in Examples 1 & 2, you could end the sentence at "prescribed" and still have a grammatically correct sentence. What follows is a prepositional phrase and such phrases are mere add-ons, of no grammatical value. However, in Examples 3 & 4, the sentences would be grammatically incorrect if they left out "for" and the words that follow "for". There is a difference between merely saying "prescribed" and saying "prescription for". There is a fundamental change in the meaning. So long as the prescription is correct, in re functionality, it makes no difference to whom it goes. A doctor may prescribe the same medicine to different diabetic patients, for instance. But a prescription for diabetes is very different from a prescription for cancer. I hope that helps.
